Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Stronger than Glass Fibers, Stiffer than Steel Wires: A New Perspective into the Mechanics of Cellulose Nanocrystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1100806 PI: Shahbazian-Yassar, Reza ORG: Michigan Tech

ID: MPS/DMR/BMAT(7623) 1100572 PI: Simonsen, John ORG: Oregon State

Title: Collaborative Research: Stronger than Glass Fibers, Stiffer than Steel Wires: A New Perspective into the Mechanics of Cellulose Nanocrystals

INTELLECTUAL MERIT: Cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) are highly crystalline organic polymers that can be extracted from natural materials. They are stiffer than aluminum and theoretical calculations place their tensile strength at 7500 MPa, higher than glass fibers or steel. Inasmuch as these crystals are biocompatible, lightweight, low cost, and sustainable they offer potential for applications in biomedical materials, energy technologies, electronics, and microelectromechanical systems devices. To date, no experimental tests have been utilized to investigate the strength properties of CNCs. This proposal aims to fill these gaps. In order to evaluate such properties the underlying mechanisms responsible for nanoscale mechanics should be determined. In-situ experiments and multiscale models for deformations in small-scale components can open possibilities for improved design and applications of CNCs. The objectives of this research are (1) to explore the nanoscale mechanics of individual CNCs as a function of the biological source, (2) to determine the dependence of CNC's mechanical properties on cellulose crystal dimensions, and (3) to fully characterize the elastic moduli of CNCs as function of their crystallographic orientations. To meet these objectives, nanomechanical properties will be investigated through the use of a novel in-situ characterization technique that enables atomic force microscopy (AFM) experiments inside the chamber of a transmission electron microscope. The in-situ data will then be used to develop and validate the continuum mechanics and molecular dynamics models of CNCs.

BROADER IMPACTS: CNC-based materials are expected to have beneficial uses in a variety of technical applications, such as composite materials, packaging, tissue engineering scaffolds, drug delivery vectors, Li-ion batteries, and electronic displays. Several exchanges of OSU and Michigan Tech students are planned to promote multidisciplinary education (microscopy, cellulose nanocrystals preparation, and computational mechanics). The PIs will recruit female and minority undergraduate research students through the Michigan Community College/University Partnership program at Michigan Tech and the Saturday Academy's Apprenticeships in Science and Engineering Program at OSU. The Michigan Tech PI will also participate in outreach activities for local high school female and underrepresented students during the Engineering Scholars Program at Michigan Tech. The Oregon State PI will increase local area awareness by providing lectures/discussions on Oregon State Public Radio. In-situ videos of microscopy experiments will also be made available to the community via YouTube©, ACS Chemical and Engineering News, and the NanoHuB© network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cellulose nanocrystals are nanoscale biofibers extracted from natural resources and offer exciting promises in applications such as sustainable structural materials and biomedical implants where mechanical properties play a great role. Before this award was granted, little knowledge existed on mechanical properties of cellulose nanocrystals at small scales. Under this award, we have followed a multidimensional path toward (1) understanding the nanomechanical properties of cellulose nanocrystals, (2) extending the microscopy methods developed in this project toward the characterization of other biomaterials and systems, and (3) educating the next generation of undergraduate and graduate students with skills and know how on nanomechanical characterization of biomaterials.

We have established a new method to characterize the mechanical property evolution at the interface between cellulose nanocrystals and the polymer matrix using atomic force microscopy (AFM). Using peak force tapping mode in AFM, we were able to characterize deformation, adhesion, and modulus gradient of the interphase region in cellulose nanocrystal composites. We also have shown that the types of resources have substantial impact on the mechanical properties of cellulose nanocomposites. In addition, for the first time, we demonstrated that in terms of mechanical properties, size matters in cellulose nanocrystals. By combining macroscale and nanoscale testing, we developed a new nanomechanical measurement method that agrees well with bulk scale testing. Interestingly, composites reinforced with cellulose nanocrystals had smaller indentation imprints and the pile-up effect increased with the increase of cellulose nanocrystal content. Due to our contribution to the science of cellulose nanocrystals, we were invited to participate in an international wide efforts led by National Research Council of Canada to characterize the mechanics of cellulose nanocrystals.

 This NSF funding has been very useful in contributing to the projects of our collaborators interested in nanomechanics of biological materials and surfaces. In an effort to explore the value of whole fish scales as a material resource, we studied the cycloid scales of the lake whitefish (Coregonus clupeaformis), in the family of Salmonidae, which are abundant and extensively harvested throughout Canada and the northern United States. We provide the first study of the nanomechanical properties of the relatively unstudied cycloid type of fish scale, and the first investigation of the ability to chemically alter the surfaces of fish scale, and the effects of those changes on the surface composition and nanomechanical properties. These studies may point the way to applications for fish scales beyond simply isolating scale components. Potential applications for scales include use as packaging additives and composite reinforcements, possibly including hydrogels. Another extension of this project was to study the dynamics of interaction between nanoparticles and biological cells with the aim to better understand the toxicity effect of nanomaterials. This study can inspire new strategies for the use of nanoparticles in several regeneration therapies. With our in situ AFM capability learned under this NSF funding, we also studied protein structures. Under storage conditions, insulin has a high propensity to aggregate via disulfide interchange reaction. In some diabetes patients’ aggregation of insulin occurs at the site of repeated injections leading to injection amyloidosis. Our results show that insulin under disulfide reducing conditions at pH and temperature close to physiological favors amorphous aggregate formation.  

This project has resulted in many opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students to engage in research on nanomechanical testing and science of biomaterials. One successful PhD defense of a minority student (female) with the thesis title of “Nanomechanics of Cellulose Crystals and Cellulose-based Polymer Composites (166 pages).” In addition two other graduate students have been supported on this grant to learn sophisticate microscopy techniques such as aberration-corrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and AFM. Two undergraduate students were involved in the projects and learned atomic force microscopy technique. Classroom teachings lectures inspired by the results of this project were delivered to undergraduate and graduate students. In particular some applications of cellulose nanocrystals for bone scaffolds were demonstrated. High school students engaged this research by lab visits over summer semesters and observing demo experiments conducted by the PI’s postdoc and PhD student. The PI taught a summary of his research work on cellulose nanocrystals as part of the MEEM 5130-Nanotechnology course, and students were engaged in projects outlining cellulose nanocrystals and their importance for U.S. economy. The results of our research are presented to the research community through 8 archival journal articles and more than 7 international conferences. Our contributions to the field of nanocomposite and cellulose have been highlighted by scientific journals and nanotechnology-related websites enabling the public to be aware of our activities under this award.

 


Last Modified: 09/05/2016
Modified by: Reza Shahbazian-Yassar
